elements.text: Ooh yes! I’m working on trying to build out some ranges internally. Someone (here I think?) also shared this resource on editorial rates:
tbh some of them seem a little low for B2B/SaaS but it’s a good baseline

text: I would say it's somewhere between those editorial freelancers association rates and this: <https://s3.amazonaws.com/b2blauncher/EdGandia_PricingGuide.pdf> But it really depends on the scope of work someone's being tasked with and the subject matter. For example, if you're hiring a freelancer to write, come up with topics based on your target audience, complete the keyword research, and interview multiple SMEs, that's going to be a bigger investment than a piece you hand off to them with a full brief.

elements.text: I would say it's somewhere between those editorial freelancers association rates and this:

But it really depends on the scope of work someone's being tasked with and the subject matter. For example, if you're hiring a freelancer to write, come up with topics based on your target audience, complete the keyword research, and interview multiple SMEs, that's going to be a bigger investment than a piece you hand off to them with a full brief.

text: Hey folks. I have a client who collects a lot of feedback via surveys throughout the customer journey. We need to find a better way to harvest testimonials from those surveys, categorize them with tags, etc. for quick sorting, and then disseminate them throughout the marketing team for use in social posts, one-pagers, etc. Has anyone developed a great system for dong this? Am I stuck doing it all manually? Does anyone have a workflow they'd be willing to share?

text: Hey <@UJJFDTN8G>, a couple that come up a lot when we talk to people is (a) how do I use GA to understand a user’s _entire journey_ better, and (b) how should I interpret bounce rate?

text:
Hey folks! :wave::skin-tone-5:
I need some tactical advice on increasing conversion % of new leads to our blog. The current conversion % is 1.5 and my key KPI is to take it to 6%. 
In the last one year we’ve increased traffic to the blog by 420%, but I’d like to know what actions I can take to get to the 6%? 
One of the ways that I can think of is through optimising user experience on the blog. What tactics have helped you? 
Please share your experiences!

elements.text: Hey folks!

I need some tactical advice on increasing conversion % of new leads to our blog. The current conversion % is 1.5 and my key KPI is to take it to 6%. 
In the last one year we’ve increased traffic to the blog by 420%, but I’d like to know what actions I can take to get to the 6%? 
One of the ways that I can think of is through optimising user experience on the blog. What tactics have helped you? 
Please share your experiences!

text: <@UL2E0QVB3> do you feel comfortable sharing the blog so I can take a look?

elements.text: do you feel comfortable sharing the blog so I can take a look?

text: Sure thing. Sending you a DM

elements.text: Sure thing. Sending you a DM

text: lookin forward to reading this post :nerd_face:

elements.text: lookin forward to reading this post

text:
Before thinking about numbers, I’d like to take three steps back :slightly_smiling_face: and ask a question:

Is the new traffic you brought to the blog _targeted_ traffic?

If it isn’t → paradoxically, the more successful you are at growing traffic, the more your CR might fall through no fault of your own

If it is → then yes, it may be time to think about UX optimisation. But it’s also time to look at the customer journey, how difficult/hard it is to convert, how many steps it takes, and all of that

elements.text: Before thinking about numbers, I’d like to take three steps back

and ask a question:

Is the new traffic you brought to the blog
targeted

traffic?

If it isn’t → paradoxically, the more successful you are at growing traffic, the more your CR might fall through no fault of your own

If it is → then yes, it may be time to think about UX optimisation. But it’s also time to look at the customer journey, how difficult/hard it is to convert, how many steps it takes, and all of that

text:
So assuming you fall into the latter scenario, you can think about:
• running some user testing to gather evidence of what’s working/what isn’t
• have a survey across the website to see if something obvious is missing from the page(s)
• look for and find drop-offs in your GA funnel 
• use this data to optimise the page(s) 
• test, repeat

elements.text: So assuming you fall into the latter scenario, you can think about:
running some user testing to gather evidence of what’s working/what isn’t
have a survey across the website to see if something obvious is missing from the page(s)
look for and find drop-offs in your GA funnel
use this data to optimise the page(s)
test, repeat

text:
Hi everyone!
Does anyone have experience with setting up multiple blogs on one site for different audiences?

We’re in the middle of a website redesign, and trying to work through how to separate our content. We would like to have a patient-focused blog (in the healthcare industry), one that’s more career focused for recruiting purposes, then one that has news about the practice. 

Are there any good examples out there about this situation to draw inspiration from?

elements.text:
Hi everyone!
Does anyone have experience with setting up multiple blogs on one site for different audiences?

We’re in the middle of a website redesign, and trying to work through how to separate our content. We would like to have a patient-focused blog (in the healthcare industry), one that’s more career focused for recruiting purposes, then one that has news about the practice.
Are there any good examples out there about this situation to draw inspiration from?

text: <@UL2E0QVB3> if you’re ok to share your blog link here, I’m happy to take a look too! and <@U017WRJTKF1>’s advice to user test is really helpful, especially if there aren’t glaring problems you already know about – you only need to do 3 - 5 to get some good insights. I’ve used <http://usertesting.com|usertesting.com> with a lot of success.

text: are you thinking of using different CMS for each?

text: i think you could accomplish this with navigation and categories vs actual different blogs

elements.text: i think you could accomplish this with navigation and categories vs actual different blogs

text: From the media world, <https://nymag.com|https://nymag.com> is a good example. They have Intelligencer (news junkies), The Cut (fashion/beauty), Vulture (TV/movies), and a few others. All are branded separately and have separate audiences, but share a sort-of hip NYCer sensibility, and roll up to the main magazine page.

attachments.title: New York Magazine
attachments.text: New York Magazine energizes people around shared interests, igniting important conversations on the news, politics, style, and culture that drive the world forward.
